CAPTION FIG1.png: 'Figure 1: Our prompt-based learning prompts for generating cross-domain analogies.\n\n'
CAPTION FIG2.png: 'Figure 2: Problem-analogy pairs used as examples in prompts for our one-shot and few-shot learning paradigm runs.\n\n'
CAPTION FIG3.png: '\n\n**Figure 3: Six design problems used for Study 1 and corresponding examples of GPT-3 generated analogies with zero-shot, one-shot, and few-shot paradigms.**'
CAPTION FIG4.png: 'Figure 4: Examples of GPI-3 generated analogies that were judged as duplicates for the same design problem "choose the right major for their college study" with zero-shot learning. These duplicate analogies shared very similar concepts/aspects with substantial verbatim overlap in terms (bolded in the figure).\n\n'
CAPTION FIG5.png: 'Figure 5: Histograms for the helpfulness ratings provided by participants for analogies in the context of the problem reformulation task in Study 1: a) all analogies, b) analogies in the first round, and c) analogies in the second round.\n\n'
CAPTION FIG6.png: 'Figure 6: **Examples of how GPT-3 generated analogies were used for reformulation by two participants (P48, top; and P109, bottom). We show the progression from their original formulation of the problem (from the initial formulation phase) to the reformulation of the problem in response to an analogy (from one of the analogical reformulation phases).**\n\n'
CAPTION FIG7.png: 'Figure 7: **Analogies that were flagged by at least 2 of the 5 raters as potentially harmful under three categories: biased, illegal, and upsetting. The subscript for each example showed how many people flagged the example as harmful.**\n\n'
CAPTION FIGA1.png: '\n\n**Figure A1: Screenshot of the initial formulation phase task interface and instructions.**'
CAPTION FIGA2.png: '\n\n**Figure A2: Screenshot of the analogical reformulation and ideation phase task interface and instructions.**'
